main event: Multiple witnesses in the Great Lakes region reported seeing a bright fireball-like object in the sky on the evening of December 9, 1965.
interesting points: The fireball was seen over a wide area, from as far east as Toronto, Canada to as far west as south central Iowa.
The fireball's path was from northwest to southeast, passing over southern Michigan, northern Indiana, and northern Ohio.
The explosion near the southeastern shore of Lake Erie was audible within a radius of 100-125 miles, with many observers thinking it was a sonic boom from an aircraft.
The fireball apparently broke up near the Earth's surface, but no fragments were recovered.
The duration of the fireball was approximately 3-4 seconds, and it traveled a distance of around 200 miles.
result: The fireball was determined to be a meteor or possible meteoritic mass.
sighted object: A bright fireball-like object in the sky
location: Great Lakes region, including Michigan, Indiana, Ohio, Pennsylvania, and Canada
